utterances: Yes.
I don't know exactly where the price break is, but I think that's their goal.
And, Marilyn, those are some of the changed habits you're talking about.
Right.
You know, when you think about where you're going to feel these price increases, as I said, the more direct it is - an egg, cheese, meat - that's where it's very direct.
If you look at something that's far more processed, let's say, a box of corn flakes, the corn that's in that box really amounts to just a few cents.
The big cost of a box of corn flakes is the box itself, the packaging, the marketing, the labeling...
The television commercials.
The commercials and the, you know, the staff it takes to put it on to the shelf, the air conditioning in the store.
There is, you know, the price of corn could double and it still would have only a marginal impact on the cost of that box.
So where this gentleman works, where you're seeing the cheese and the meat very directly, that's where you're going to really feel it.
So people can shift their breakfast.
Instead of having a cheese omelet, you might want to think about corn flakes.
Cameron, thanks very much for the call.
You're very welcome.
Have a great day.
And good luck to you.
And our thanks to Lester Brown of the Earth Policy Institute and to Marilyn Geewax.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Joel Rising has surely had this experience.
Many frequent travelers have, a screaming baby on the airplane.
But what's that baby doing there anyway?
Is it safe for infants to fly?
Doctor Sydney Spiesel is a pediatrician and a professor at Yale Medical School, as well as a contributor to slate.com.
And when we spoke earlier, I asked him if a new study out on this topic had any answers.
What the study says is, if you have normal kids, yes, you know, when you're flying, the air pressure goes down in a plane.
It's as if we were walking around the top of a mountain that's maybe 5,000 feet.
The amount of oxygen that's available for absorption is about three quarters because of the lower pressures.
About three quarters of that - of the same amount as sea level.
And young children we know don't do quite as well with lower oxygen levels as older.
But, in fact, millions of kids fly, and they really fly quite well without problems.
And no problems for their ears?
Well, there sometimes are problems for their ears.
I mean, whenever you hear a kid screaming their brains out behind you or in front of you on a plane, probably that kid is having air pressure problems.

And what happens is that, if they can't pop their ears very well - that is, popping your ears is equalizing the pressure in the middle ear with that in the atmosphere around you, which we mostly do by making those funny little motions with our jaw and swallowing and things like that - little kids often don't know how to do that.
What can happen is that, as the pressure in the plane drops, the pressure in the middle ear remains at sea level, and so the ear drum gets stretched.
And ear drums don't like to get stretched.
Sometimes they get stretched badly enough so that they can even tear, although that's really quite rare.
One of the things that it does lead to is terrible pain sometimes for kids.
I always recommend that parents give kids something to drink and sometimes just sort of chewing on a candy increases saliva, so that you swallow, and it allows pressure to equalize.
OK, so for kids who are not healthy, what about them?
Well, some of them are - it is a problem.

You know, the ones that come to mind right away are kids who are really significantly premature and who are in the newborn special care unit for a while and who have this chronic lung disease that we sometimes see in graduates of the newborn care unit.
Those kids might need extra oxygen.

Sometimes we recommend that those kids - the parents talk to a pulmonologist before flying because there are tests that can be done that indicate what will happen if the oxygen level drops a little bit.

Some of those kids are going to need extra oxygen, which the airlines - you can always arrange that in advance with the airlines, although sometimes the supplemental oxygen comes with a supplemental price.
Now, what about taking medication on board?
Because if kids have maybe other problems, like asthma or cystic fibrosis, heart disease, whatever, things that need treatment on the plane, is that hard now to get that in your carry-on baggage?
It's hard.
In fact, I very strongly - especially for kids with asthma, I very strongly recommend that you should absolutely bring them onboard.

However, in this day and age of airport security problems and so forth, it's really important to bring a copy of the prescription with you, so that you can show - as you check in, you can say, look, my doctor says I need to have this.
Thank you, Syd.
Thank you.
That's Dr. Sydney Spiesel.
He's a pediatrician and a Yale Medical School professor.
And he comes to us via the online magazine, Slate.
Baltimore has a new hero - Cahree Myrick.
He's 12 years old and the first national youth chess champion that that city has ever had.
Two weeks ago in Nashville, he won a perfect score, 7-0.
He took his division at the U.S.
Chess Federation SuperNationals.
Cahree Myrick joins us on the line now from Baltimore.
Congratulations.
Thanks for being with us.
Thank you.
It's been a big opportunity for me to just being able to go there and do what I had to do.
Where'd you learn chess?
I learned at my elementary school, The Green School of Baltimore.
My chess coach taught me there.
Why did you take up chess?
What interested you?
Well, I was in first grade, and I just liked the way the pieces looked.
And then I told my mom about it, and she just signed me up.
Oh, that's wonderful.
Now I'm told you've played many games for practice in the back of a barbershop there in Baltimore.
Yes.
Well, I learned how to play at my elementary school, then I just go on and play at my barbershop.
People whose names you can share with us?
Yes, my barber, Sundiata and the other barbers that are in there - Adwalia (ph).
These are adults, right?
Yes.
Think they were giving you any breaks?
Probably not.
No, they played me like I was any other customer.
Yeah.
Can you tell us the moves that you made in Nashville that were particularly - I'm afraid I don't know much about chess.
But people listening who know about chess might be impressed.
My opening that I play is the Scandinavian, but that's on black.
And I think I was black my last winning game.
The Scandinavian is an opening on black when the queen's pawn is pushed up two squares.
Now you're a seventh-grader at the Roland Park Middle School.
Yes.
Do you get kidded about being the chess champ?
No. Actually a lot of people think it's cool.
And a lot of my friends actually try to play me even though none of them know how to actually play.
(Laughter) Well, you do have that advantage, don't you?
Yes.
Cahree, there's been some thinking over the years that young people who excel at chess find that that spills over into other areas of their studies and their schoolwork.
Have you found that?
(Soundbite of music)
So you think it's helped you in planning, organization, that sort of thing?
Yeah, and everything is just being focused in school because in order to be successful, you absolutely need to know how to focus.
You're 12 years old - any idea what you want to be when you're an adult?
Well, chess-wise I want to become a grandmaster, but in - otherwise I don't actually know yet.
